It‚Äôs clear the value and trust in a blue check mark is now dead after the flurry of high profile, viral impersonations. It might take a week or two for people to fully realize this, but once they do, even the residual value to scammers will be gone. The mark will be meaningless.

@carrickdb not necessarily though if the initial input buffer was created without null termination and written right up to the boundary - as you say we can't even assume that :)
@carrickdb If there‚Äôs no null you‚Äôd eventually hit uninitialized memory and crash with no risk of code exec in your count loop.

@carrickdb You'd not trust the calling function; your function would count the bytes of the input buffer (assuming null termination). Problem is you'd need to call an *alloc if inline assembly is not allowed under terms of the question and you'd not be able to trust that.

@carrickdb Rather than the calling function supplying the output buffer, the function you‚Äôre writing could provide it based upon length of input buffer? Assuming you also avoid integer wraps etc, too. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
